The patient presents with severe retrosternal chest pain and pain when swallowing solid food and medications, with a recent history of oral corticosteroids. These symptoms and the endoscopy results suggest that the patient has a gastrointestinal ulcer likely caused by the alendronate. Discontinuing the medication is the most appropriate next step in management. Starting ganciclovir is not indicated as there is no indication of viral infection. Pantoprazole may be helpful in treating the ulcer, but discontinuing the offending medication is still necessary. Discontinuing amlodipine is not indicated as there is no evidence to suggest that it is causing the patient's symptoms.

The upper endoscopy findings suggest an esophageal ulcer, which could be caused by alendronate. Discontinuation of alendronate is recommended as the most appropriate next step in management. Ganciclovir is used in the treatment of viral infections, not for esophageal ulcers. Pantoprazole could be used to treat GERD, but it is not the most appropriate next step in this case. Amlodipine is unlikely to be the cause of the patient's symptoms and discontinuing it is not necessary.
